ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The readings were much more time intensive than any other course, and I often could not finish them each week. Thesis sentences forum was helpful for that reason (when I couldn't finish the readings myself).

Question 12: This course was valuable mostly in that it asked students who want to work in the fields of international development (and to a lesser extent, conservation) to examine their assumptions and the power relations inherent in the type of work they do. It was more theory-based and less couched in terms of students own experiences than I would have liked.

I took this class as a foundational introduction to social science, hoping it would be particularly focused on the conservation side (vs. the development side). It turned out to be more focused on development theory than on conservation, but there were still some interesting conservation readings. It's also heavy into anthropology, but I should have known that since it was cross-listed in the anthro department. It was more anthropology than I cared to learn, but it still provided a good introduction to social science theory.

The instructor did little to create a comprehensive narrative for the class. It felt like a jumbled collection of readings with no clear theme. Lecture should be used to frame "big picture" ideas and questions that contextualize the readings. The instructor said little that was comprehensible about how everything tied together. Additionally, there is far too much focus on Foucauldian analyses of conservation and development. I would appreciate seeing a greater diversity of readings from Marxian and other frameworks. The instructor could also be better about accepting non-Foucauldian explanations. The class was too large to have productive discussion. The size should be smaller or there should be a greater focus on the lecture. Or the class could be broken into two discussion groups.
Question 12. The class was very helpful in improving critical thinking in the field of development and conservation.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The readings
The reading material was great; there was just too much of it. I liked the theoretical stuff the most.
Identifying argument and developing a thesis sentence
The readings were the best part. Although there is a lot to read, all the authors are great and you learn a lot with it.
The readings
The wide range of readings and the class discussions.

The in-class discussions, which towards the second half of the semester became very interesting. It took the class a long time to feel comfortable with addressing the serious questions that the class brought up in discussions, and I think this contributed to discussion at the beginning of the course being somewhat stilted or lackluster.

Some of the readings were painful to get through for someone with no background in anthro or in development theory, but the weekly thesis sentence exercise was great. Hugely helpful in learning how to do these readings and a good skill to develop for complicated readings of any kind.

I appreciated the format of having a discussion session for the latter half of each class that allows everyone to talk about the day's topic - the talking and sharing of ideals and interpretations really helps.
The students in the class brought a diverse set of perspectives--I wish that I heard more about those in discussion.
Carol's lectures are fantastic on the whole. I enjoyed the respectful, candid discussion with my peers.
Writing thesis sentences is very helpful to train my reading skills.
Writing thesis sentences each week was a very valuable exercise. I also enjoyed the discussion section of each class meeting.
The readings and discussions were great, even though everyone was not always participating I think we got a lot out of it.
The student-led discussions were a good way to explore the concepts brought up in the course readings.
That it encouraged us to develop critical thinking abilities.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Discussion leadership by instructor; lectures
The longer writing assignments were structured in too specific of a way - inhibited exploration of ideas, and grade points were deducted for seemingly unimportant things

I think it would be useful to hand in a draft of the final paper in the end of October or so. This helps not doing the final paper in the last minute. It would be helpful to get some concepts explained in the first or second class, so then students who don't have a background in SS could better understand the readings.
connecting the readings to larger theoretical frameworks within conservation and developing. not just who the authors are, but how they contribute to larger literary tendencies and philosophies.
I think the lectures could be more straight forward and focused, and less desultory.

The professor's lectures were often disorganized. There was no clear thread running throughout the course to help students make sense of the material in context, or in relation to materials addressed the week before. More contextualization and more organized lectures would be helpful.

I found the student-led discussion portion of the class just painful, on most occasions. Stilted conversation doesn't help anybody; but that was in part the nature of the group and the classroom (big room, big class with all kinds of different levels of background in the subject material). It was much better on days where Carol was actively participating in the student discussion part. I wish there had been more of a focus on drawing from peoples' past experiences, but that's not the professor or the course's fault - people just didn't seem that interested in volunteering stories about themselves.
The readings can be quite difficult for people with no social sciences background.
See question 13.
Teaching!

Carol commented a lot in the first couple of weeks about the quality of our thesis sentences. Initially, she provided her own examples and highighted good ones from our peers. However, when asked for more specifics on constructing a good sentence, she seemed very unwilling to provide guidance. She asked if we could not tell what a good sentence was, which did not address how she actually reads and evaluates our sentences. There was never any rubric or indication of how she was grading them. And, instead of stating that anyone who was interested could request feedback, it would be more helpful to just provide feedback on everyone's sentences for the first couple of weeks. The due date of the final paper is way too early.

The second half of the class relied on a group of students leading a discussion on the week's readings. Many discussion questions students posed were premised on conclusions a student facilitator reached from the reading requiring lengthly background explanation or were framed in a way where they were really trying to present a statement rather than a question. As such, discussion at times was minimal or went on tangents (which is not necessarily bad). I would have liked to see the professor facilitate the discussions for at least the first two weeks of class. Though the discussions improved, facilitation is an art that can be learned from first by seeing how it should be conducted. Also it would have been great for the professor to emphasize students developing how to lead focused and in depth discussions as she did for emphasizing the importance of critical reading.

The lecture portion of the class time provided a lot of useful information and helped tie the readings and concept together, however it was sometimes unclear what exactly we were supposed to get out of the lectures. Posting copies of all of the lectures could have been helpful as well.
Some of the readings were practically unintelligible for students who did not have an anthropological background.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Discussions were very effective and helped understand the texts.
Yes, but the discussions were not too guided and deep enough

The lectures really helped see the overarching theme in the readings. I don't think the author bios are very relevant, though. The time spent on those could be spent on providing more background and history on the theme and concepts.
Directly related.
Not at all.
Very helpful, I think the discussions followed the lectures well. The articles depicted the topics discussed in lectures well.
Yes. It could be improved by replacing some of the lectures for more introductory ones, less cryptic.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It improved my English
It has given me a good foundation on the effects of conservation and development projects from the viewpoint of anthropology.

As someone who perhaps plans to work in international development and/or conservation, this course gave me the valuable opportunity to examine my own assumptions that I might bring to this type of work. It helped me look critically at the work I might do and think about whether or not it is ethical work, and how to engage in this type of work in a more participatory and equitable manner.

It turned out to be only tangentially related to my interests (I was hoping for more of a focus on conservation than on development, when it was the other way around). But as long as you know that going in, you won't be surprised.
Helped me to understand the social implications of implementation of conservation and strategic decisions.
It develops my analytical skills, to see better any aspects of my work in development sector.
The course was helpful in terms of my career goals;however, I have no social science background and found the course difficult in the beginning, especially the readings.
For me, this course is pretty much exactly what I came to F&ES to study....conservation and development. This course was a fantastic introduction to the social science side of these issues.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I work with development and this course is useful to be critical about development and seeing pros and cons of development
I wanted to learn the perspective of anthropology
My backgroung is in Biology, so I am interested in learning more about sustainable development from the social sciences perspective.
Wanted/needed an introduction to basic social science & theory.
Required component of the Master of Forestry program.
I thought the syllabus was interesting.
To help me with my research on social studies.
To better understand my past involvement in development and to help inform my point/posture of intervention in the future.
It was one of the fundamental courses for the specialization and also fit in well with my career goals.
See Question 17 answer.
Because I wanted to critically think about the consequences and implication of policy intervention in the name of development.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes, it did.

Yes and it was better than I expected. I think SS courses generally have a stereotype of being hard and confusing, but I found Carpenter's class to be very neat, both the mandatory texts and class discussions.
Reading more effectively

It has helped me learn about other conservation and development projects around the world, and to be critical of the way government and NGOs work, and to be aware of the ever-present power relations in such projects. I would have liked, however, for the class to include readings where there were not only criticism on projects but something that actually made proposals on how projects might actually work best.

Yes, although I expected a bit more structure and to maybe have some constructive criticism of conservation and development as opposed to what largely turned out to be critique without alternative suggestions.

Sort of. Wish it was more focused on social science generally and less on anthropology if it is going to be billed as a social science Foundations class. Or, there should be more clearer direction as to why one might take this class over Dove's social science class.
Yes.
No! Definitely no!
Far exceeded! What a wonderful introduction to the best in this body of literature! I am very thankful to have taken this course.
Yes, pretty much.
Yes, for the most part - it gave me much to consider and helped me think more critically, which is what I was interested in.
Yes, definitely. I think it was a great introductory course for someone who had not had social sciences before.
Yes, we were told to expect to get to know the literature on this subject and to gain critical thinking skills and I feel like I got exactly that.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Student-led discussions were mostly fruitful on the weeks that I was assigned to hold discussion.
We had to lead a group discussion so it was better not to lead it alone.
Not many, as there was no continuous group work which allowed to establish relationships

It was very helpful to discuss the articles for my comparative analysis with the group and the TA. This helped me see aspects of the readings I had not considered and sometimes solve the questions I had come up with while reading.

In groups, we lead class discussions for 2 days of the semester. This was easier to do in a group than as an individual simply because we had more heads to think of possible questions and ideas about how to guide discussion.
Developing thoughts for the student-led discussion with your mini-group was helpful. Some good conversation came out of our individual group meetings with Ashwini, the TA.
Better preparation and exchange of ideas.
Generally a good experience.
Working with the group helped in understanding the concepts better. Discussing the readings prior to the class helped in writing the reading commentaries.
It was a good way to exchange points of view and learn how different people with different backgrounds interpreted the material given.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Prof Carpenter is pretty bad with names, except for a select few students who appear to be her favorites.
I encourage to take
Read the texts and plan in advance for your final paper.

It is a good basis in the social science critique of development, and to a lesser extent conservation. Lectures can be a bit hard to follow, however, and the course as a whole is not very cohesive. A better course for self-starters than those who need a lot of structure given.
Be aware that it is mostly focused on the anthropology of development, with a little conservation worked in. For that purpose, it's pretty effective.
It is all about Foucault.
If there are not significant changes in the structure of the course, then I would recommend students NOT take it.
The course is heavy on reading and should be combined with classes that do not require as much weekly reading.

Even if you don't have any background in social science (I didn't!), this is a very useful and accessible course. Also, if you want feedback on your thesis sentences or feel unsure about your understanding of the material, ask!
To be aware that the course draws heavily on anthopological concepts and authors.
